Title:
Titanoceratops ouranos, a giant horned dinosaur from the late
Campanian of New Mexico.
Journal:
Titanoceratops ouranos, a giant horned dinosaur from the
late Campanian of New Mexico
Keywords:
Body size; Ceratopsidae; Chasmosaurinae; Cretaceous;
Dinosauria
Abstract:
At the end of the Cretaceous, 65.5 million years ago, the
giant ceratopsids Triceratops and Torosaurus dominated North AmericaÂ’s
dinosaur fauna. The origins of these giant ceratopsids, the
Triceratopsini, are poorlyunderstood. This paper describes
Titanoceratops ouranos, a giant ceratopsid fromthe lateCampanian
(73e74Ma) of NewMexico, and the earliest known triceratopsin. The
holotypewas previously interpreted as an aberrant and exceptionally
large specimen of Pentaceratops sternbergi, but the animal does not show
the diagnostic features of Pentaceratops. Instead, cladistic analysis
shows that Titanoceratops is the sister taxon of a clade formed by
Eotriceratops, Triceratops, and Torosaurus. With an estimated mass of
6.5 tons, Titanoceratops is among the largest dinosaurs known from the
Campanian of North America, and rivaled Triceratops in size. The
recognition of Titanoceratops suggests that giant chasmosaurines evolved
once, among the Triceratopsini, and that the group evolved large size
five million years earlier than previously thought. The giant horned
dinosaurs probably originated in the southern part of the North American
continent during the Campanian but only became widespread during the
Maastrichtian.
